block.p: House Approves Money For Colombia Drug War The House approved an $11.2 billion spending bill that included emergency aid to battle drug traffickers and their rebel allies in Colombia, finance peacekeeping in Kosovo and provide disaster relief to flood and fire victims in the United States.

Compromise on Tribunal The United States won an agreement to keep the door open to further talks on its demand that no American official or soldier be surrendered to the permanent court for war crimes as long as Washington has not signed the treaty creating the court.

No Haste on Mideast Summit Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, in Jerusalem for meetings with Israeli and Palestinian leaders, said the Clinton administration did not feel pressured to call a summit meeting immediately.

Kohl Remains Defiant The former Chancellor of Germany, Helmut Kohl, appeared before a parliamentary committee investigating financial misdeeds under his rule, and he said he was a victim of slander. His stance was consistent with the defiance he has shown since his admission that he took about $1 million in undeclared payments from donors and used the money to bolster the Christian Democratic Party.

Refugees Feared Drowned An overloaded Indonesian ferry appeared to have sunk in heavy seas on route from Halmahera Island, and officials said they feared the loss of nearly 500 people, many of whom were fleeing religion-based killings in the remote Maluku Islands.

Vote in Uganda Ugandans voted in an unusual referendum on how they want to be governed, a question tied deeply to the violence of the nation's past and the popularity of President Yoweri Museveni, who in large measure has ended that violence.

Abortion Foes Begin Work Drafting New Legislation A day after the Supreme Court struck down a law barring a procedure called by opponents partial-birth abortion, supporters of such bans said they were planning a new spate of laws they hoped would withstand further legal challenges.

Opening Books of Groups The Senate followed the House in approving a bipartisan bill to require tax-exempt groups that raise and spend money on political causes to disclose donors and expenditures. The president will sign it.

Some Elderly to Lose Coverage H.M.O.'s will cancel insurance coverage for more than 700,000 Medicare beneficiaries next year because the H.M.O.'s are cutting back their participation in Medicare, an industry trade group announced.

G.O.P. Patient Rights Bill The Senate voted, 51 to 47 largely on party lines, for limited patient protections, including a restricted right to sue H.M.O.'s, in legislation backed by the Republican majority.

Cuban Exile Lobby Not Yielding The Cuban American National Foundation began reorganizing its leadership and pledged to spend ''whatever it takes'' to preserve hard-line United States policies toward Cuba.

Commerce Secretary Nominee President Clinton nominated a former Democratic Congressman from California, Norman Y. Mineta, for secretary of commerce. Mr. Mineta would be the first Asian-American to hold a Cabinet post.

Fire at Nuclear Complex A fire ignited by a traffic accident swept the sagebrush at the Hanford nuclear complex in Washington State, burning across three radioactive waste sites. But officials said they had detected no release of radiation.

Decision on Alaska Airlines The F.A.A. accepted Alaska Airlines' remedial plan and will not shut down its maintenance operation, even though the agency found that the airline had allowed mechanics to perform work for which they were not qualified, skipped maintenance on test equipment and failed to tell pilots about inoperable equipment.

Copy of 'Declaration' Fetches $7.4 Million Online A copy of the Declaration of Independence printed in 1776 and found behind a $4 flea-market painting in 1989 was sold over the Internet by Sotheby's for $7.4 million.

Why Reactor Wasn't Upgraded Con Edison decided in 1997 not to replace the steam generator that later caused an accident at the Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor, in Westchester County, because of uncertainty over the financial effects in the deregulated market that was developing, an internal document says.

Judge Cites Restaurant Union A federal judge cited New York's largest union of restaurant workers for contempt of court, finding it had defamed the Metropolitan Opera and improperly harassed board members as part of an effort to unionize 95 restaurant workers at the Met.
Drug Takes Weight Off Mice An experimental cancer drug, C75, made lab mice lose large amounts of weight without side effects.
Cleveland Slugger to Yanks The Yankees sent outfielder Ricky Ledee and two minor league players to be named to the Indians for outfielder David Justice.
Rocker in New York Heavy security surrounded John Rocker's presence in Manhattan and journey to Shea Stadium, by police van, not the No. 7 subway line.
Suspensions Are Lifted Baseball's chief operating officer overturned 12 of the suspensions imposed against 19 Los Angeles Dodgers for brawling with Cubs fans.
Pierce Gone From Wimbledon The French Open champion Mary Pierce lost to the 49th-ranked Magui Serna, 7-6 (5), 7-6 (4).

New Leader for Conseco Gary C. Wendt, who built GE Capital Services into a financial services powerhouse, was named chairman and chief executive of Conseco. The beleaguered insurance giant has been struggling the last two years, partly because of its costly acquisition of Green Tree Financial, which finances mobile-home purchases.

Effort to Trim Drug Spending Rx Health Value, a coalition of 69 health plans, several large employers, unions and consumer advocates, is beginning a campaign to slow spending on prescription drugs fueled by pharmaceutical marketing and advertising campaigns aimed at doctors and consumers.
Vittorio Gassman The versatile film star, who was also one of Italy's leading classical stage actors, was 77.
Charles A. MacGillivary A former Army sergeant awarded the Medal of Honor for a one-man foray against German machine-gun positions during the Battle of the Bulge, he was 83.
Editorials: Mr. Nader's misguided crusade; watching Mexico's election; privatization and failing schools; the AIDS epidemic in Africa. Columns: Gail Collins.
